meta-review.comment:
Hippo Penny - Here's my take on Watch Dogs, a game that had me going from zero to hero in no time! Or should I say, from zero to vigilante?

Now, I know what you're thinking: "Another open-world action game? How original." But hear me out. Watch Dogs brings something fresh to the table - or rather, the Chicago streets. You play as Aiden Pearce, a hacker with a penchant for causing chaos and mayhem in a city that's ripe for revolution.

The game's main draw is its hacking abilities, which are ridiculously fun (and sometimes frustratingly tricky). You'll use your smartphone to hack into various systems, from traffic lights to security cameras. It's like being the ultimate troublemaker - minus the whole "getting caught by authorities" part.

But let's get real for a sec. The critics were eating this game up like it was a delicious plate of Chicago-style deep dish pizza (yes, that's a thing). IGN gave it an 84, saying it's "fundamentally very well made." GameSpot echoed similar sentiments with their 80 score, praising the game's ability to keep you engaged. Even Vandal, those notorious party poopers, gave it a 87, saying it's "a great surprise."

Now, I know some of you might be thinking, "Wait, what about the gang warfare?" Listen, while that part can get a bit repetitive, the real meat and potatoes (or should I say, the real hack and slash?) is in the game's world-building. The attention to detail in Chicago is impressive, and it really feels like you're exploring a living, breathing city.

So, what do I think? Well, let's just say I'm not as cool as Aiden Pearce (who is?), but I did have a blast playing Watch Dogs. It's a great game that will keep you entertained for hours on end. And who knows? You might even learn something about cybersecurity along the way (just kidding... or am I?).

In conclusion, if you're looking for an open-world action game with some serious bite and brains, Watch Dogs is the way to go. Just don't get too caught up in hacking all the traffic lights - trust me, it gets old after a while.
